newsitem.title: UK: LME copper above $2,000 by close, others quiet.
newsitem.headline: LME copper above $2,000 by close, others quiet.

text.p: London Metal Exchange (LME) copper prices looked to establish a foothold above $2,000 a tonne by the close of business on Monday, though profit-taking and speculative selling was emerging to cap the move.
Benchmark three months copper was last at $2,012, down $3 from its high, but up on Friday's LME kerb close of $2,007.
Traders said the market continues to consolidate ahead of Tuesday's LME stocks which are expected to fall. Currently inventories stand at six-year lows of 113,400 tonnes.
On the charts resistance is pegged at $2,040, while support was expected to emerge at $1,985.
Tight nearby spreads continued to buoy copper. The cash to three months backwardation was little changed at $75.
News that a strike at Chile's Candelaria copper mine had ended after six days failed to impact seriously on prices, as production at the 150,000 tonne facility had not been affected.
Aluminium after testing support below $1,450 snapped back to close at $1,448, though this was still $2 down on Friday.
Traders said aluminium is now likely to trend sideways, though a stocks rise on Tuesday may prompt selling.
A 96,000 tonne fall in total IPAI stocks in September to four-year lows of 3.257 million tonnes failed to impact.
Nickel, after an earlier chase lower with copper to $7,170, recovered some of its poise to end at $7,200, a loss of $60.
Zinc also recovered earlier lost ground following sell-stop activity down to $1,051. It was last at $1,060, down $4.
Lead was $3 lower at $732. Tin was indicated $5,915/25, versus $5,925.
